Same view, different angle
By Jessie Ansons
I make the final turn at the top of the concrete ramp and see three rectangular openings that overlook Newcastle Harbour. The path stops abruptly, reminding me of the tower that used to be here, connected by an overpass. Now it's completely bricked up, painted a muted yellow to match the other three walls. A perfect blank canvas.
The tower itself is long gone, deemed too costly for the city to maintain. It's a shame. The cost would have been a drop in the ocean compared to all the other spending going on at the time. Perhaps it wasn't about cost at all. Perhaps the tower was simply too beige, and not enough bourgeois, for Newcastle's changing image.
I'm lost in my thoughts and memories of the past when I hear footsteps on the gritty concrete behind me. I turn to see Scott, his grey hair its usual wild mess and a wide grin on his gorgeous face.
'I got distracted by the graffiti,' he explains. 'The layers upon layers done by thousands of people, with no overarching plan... yet somehow it's come together to create this masterpiece. Incredible!' He waves his arms around the space excitedly.
His eyes scan the concrete around us. This dead-end space has attracted late-night partiers and teenagers looking for fun. The graffiti is thick on every wall and empty cans and broken bottles pile in the corner. The lingering smell of urine bothers my nose, but I try to ignore it.
There's a pillow too without its pillowcase, and my heart aches for the person who chose this place to sleep. Was it a young person? Someone with nowhere else to go? Someone who, if life had taken a slightly different turn, could be sleeping in a plush king-size bed in one of the renovated apartments just across the road?
My mind fills with worry and what-ifs. I've always had a deep care for kids, a natural maternal instinct from a very young age. People loved to point it out. When I played with my dolls: 'You're going to make a great mum one day!' When I babysat my sister's newborn and rocked him to sleep: 'Just wait till it's your turn!' When my good friend consoled me at the end of a long-term relationship: 'Your time will come, don't worry!'
And, when my doctor confirmed my time was up, 'have you thought of getting a pet?'
I've lived in this city my entire life, but for the 30 years the tower was open, I never once took the climb to the top. I'd always intended to, just never found the right time. Or the right person to do it with.
Apparently, the view from up there was incredible. Panoramic vistas of the city, the harbour and the sea. A place to watch the coal ships coming in to port, see the giant fig trees in the park from up above. The best place to fully appreciate everything this great city had to offer.
Yet I remember my sister complaining that the stairs were a killer, all 180 of them. And exposed to the elements, a cold wind pierced her skin every step and rattled the metal frame. She said by the time she got to the top she was too exhausted to truly appreciate anything. And the windows were terrible. The scratched Perspex made her feel like she was wearing glasses of the wrong prescription while trying to make out the shape of Whibayganba.
Perhaps she was trying to make me feel better knowing I'd never been to the top.
Now that I'm looking at the bricked-up wall before me, do I wish I'd made the climb? The Novocastrian rite of passage. That dream is over and it's too late now. Newcastle has moved on, the tower forgotten. Other than those brief moments when someone finds a commemorative bottle opener in the back of their cutlery drawer and exclaims, 'Remember that weird-shaped tower in town?'
For 30 years this concrete ramp was a hive of movement. People navigating mobility scooters, riding bikes, pushing prams. The ramp connected to the base of the tower, which then connected over to Hunter Street Mall. A thoroughfare for workers and tourists alike. Now, it's a ramp to nowhere.
Or is it? Scott wraps me in a hug and together we look out at the view. The sun is setting to the west and the ferry returns from across the harbour, framed by one of the rectangles. The golden strip of sky at the horizon blends seamlessly into the blue sky above. Other than the ferry, the harbour is empty. A still, perfect calm. I wonder if it would have looked different 40 metres up. Same view, but from a different angle.
I ask, 'If the tower was still here, you would have climbed it with me, right?'
Scott holds me a little tighter, but he doesn't answer. The fact neither of us have kids is one of the things that brought us together later in life. Two lives well-lived, but with a mutual understanding that there'd always be something of a gap.
I lean a little further into Scott's warmth, his strong arms holding me close. The ferry docks at the wharf and a flock of white corellas changes direction overhead, looking to settle in one of the park's big old fig trees. The view at the top of the ramp is absolutely stunning. Even without the tower to climb.
Noodle's Moment of Glory
by Glen Fredericks
I was born for greatness, forged in the fires of destiny - and also under the dining table.
It was a Tuesday morning. The kettle was boiling. Someone dropped toast. And there I emerged, squinting into the light like a newborn warrior glimpsing his first battlefield.
Some say heroes are shaped by adversity; I was shaped mostly by crumbs. But still, greatness was in my veins. I could feel it. Mostly in the tail region, where feelings are stored. My name is Noodle, though in my imagination it's something more epic, like "Lord Noodleford the Swift." My legs, you see, are short but powerful. Well... short. But destiny knows how to work around these things, and it had plans for me.
Every hero requires a rival. I, unfortunately, have Sir Wiggleton the Third. He is everything I despise in a dog: well-groomed, symmetrical, and unbearably smug. His coat shines like polished mahogany. His owner speaks to him exclusively in French, which is, frankly, unnecessary on Australian soil.
When Sir Wiggleton struts past, all chest and attitude, I often project the thought "Move along, Sir Wigglebum". My telepathy, to be clear, works none of the time, but I refuse to let that undermine the science. Yet somehow, Wiggleton always snaps his head in my direction, eyes squinting, as if he felt the insult. It is my greatest joy.
Preparing for the Dachshund Dash was no simple feat. A champion must train as such. Leaf Sprints: Every afternoon, when the wind carried a crisp, fluttering leaf across the lawn, I would explode into motion at an estimated 4.5 kilometres per hour. Possibly five, on days when I hadn't eaten too much. Vacuum Combat: My sworn enemy. Huge, roaring, uncaring. I fought it bravely, barking with the fury of 10,000 warriors from behind the couch. One must know when to pick battles. Focus Training: staring intensely at a single piece of kibble, I would channel all inner energy... until I fell asleep. Meditation is important. Spiritual Digging: To dig is to know oneself, and there's still a bone out there somewhere.
Destiny enjoys burying things.
My owner observed all this and said, "Noodle's having a silly five minutes." Silly? No. I was preparing for glory.
The Dachshund Dash is the doggy equivalent of the Melbourne Cup, except shorter, louder, and with significantly more drool.
The moment we arrived, chaos assaulted my senses. Dogs in costumes. Owners shouting. Children squealing. A man selling hot chips walked past, and I briefly lost contact with reality. I inhaled deeply. The air tasted like grass, anticipation, and chicken salt. I attempted telepathy with my owner, signalling her chosen one was ready.
She smiled. "Who wants a drink of water?"
Telepathy remains a work in progress.
Across the field stood Sir Wiggleton, wearing a miniature racing saddle and a look of aristocratic disdain. I projected another thought beam at him: "Nice saddle, Wigglebum." Again, he flinched. Victory.
We lined up behind the starting hay bale barrier. The whistle blew. The crowd roared. And I launched myself forward in what I believed was a blur of aerodynamic sausage.
A streak of lightning. A brown furry torpedo slicing through the air. I was later informed I was moving at a "gentle trot" and was "in last place out of six."
Fake news, obviously. Up ahead, the pack thundered down the field with frightening commitment. Sir Wiggleton was already near the front, ears pinned back like a show-off. The others followed, legs pumping like tiny pistons. I, Noodle, remained calm. Greatness requires patience.
Then, destiny intervened. A human, clumsy, careless, possibly an agent of fate, dropped a fresh, steaming sausage roll near the sideline. Time slowed. Wiggleton spotted it first. His eyes widened. His nostrils flared. He veered sideways so violently he nearly rolled himself. The others followed instantly. The entire leading pack folded inward like magnetised hot dogs, crashing into each other, tumbling head over paws.
A hay bale toppled. Someone screamed. Wiggleton yelled something in French, possibly a profanity, possibly "pastry!" And me? Because I was so far behind, I simply trotted past the heap of wriggling chaos.
A perfect Steven Bradbury moment. Just like the speed skater, the hero of heroes, who won gold because everyone else wiped out in front of him. I felt spiritually connected to him. We're both athletes, after all. Both misunderstood champions. The crowd erupted in cheers. I crossed the finish line. I won. I, Noodle, had Bradburied them.
The officials placed a tiny ribbon on my collar. Cameras flashed. But in that moment, I felt no joy. By the time I reached the scene of the great sausage roll incident, they had eaten all of it. Every crumb. Every flake of pastry. Gone. My stomach whimpered. My heart cracked in two. The true spoil of war, devoured without me. I stared at the empty grass, wondering how victory could taste like nothing at all. History will remember this as my Bradbury moment.
I, however, will remember it as the day destiny cheated me out of lunch.
Sea of Hope
By Julie Pearce
When all else failed, she headed for the surf. She enjoyed the coarse grit between her toes as her feet sank with every step. With little care, she flung her towel upon the sand. Sunlight spilled over her face, warming her skin, revealing her lined, weary features. In the distance a couple strolled along the waters' edge. Their figures small against the endless sweep of sand.
Board riders broke the silence, paddling out to meet the swell. Their voices raised in excitement as a curious dolphin joined them, circling in playful dives, teasing and changing direction each time they neared. Everyone seemed to have a tribe.
She wondered if the feeling of belonging had passed her by, or was it simply taking the long way around?
From an early age she had sat on the sidelines of life. Made to feel bad, just for being herself. Ignored by her peers in the schoolyard. Too peculiar in her habits, too quiet when she spoke. Her peers were all about parties and boyfriends. She couldn't envision a partner by her side. Surrounded by others, she had never felt so alone.
The only companion throughout her teenage years had been a waif of a dog with questionable breeding. All he'd ever required was a belly rub and the chance of a stroll around the block. They were a pair of strays, forgiving of each other's faults. He had been a sloppy eater. She, a professional worrier. Quiet evenings had been spent cuddled together upon the couch. When Ernie passed she had been the sole mourner.
Stuck in a negative loop, she possessed neither desire nor energy to interact with anyone. Unfocused, her mind would spin like a tumble drier, endlessly spiralling. What if a plane crashed through her bedroom window? What if she was murdered in her sleep? What if they stopped making her favourite pizza? The one with pineapple, mushrooms and generous lashings of cheese that combined to dribble out of her mouth onto her chin?
She was reminded by her therapist that her struggles didn't define her, although her path would be laden with potholes. The medication made her to tired and grumpy. Sleeping for whole days until the dosage had been adjusted. She dreamed of feeling normal, happy, and with purpose before admitting to herself that life didn't work like that. It could be complicated and messy.
A trip to the beach to relax and place things in perspective had been exactly what the doctor had ordered. It had only taken a single outing to seal her unease about what might be lurking in the shallows.
As the water gently lapped around her legs, she felt a tickling sensation, then an unexpected tug. Her anxiety betrayed her as she imagined jaws preparing to strike. Turns out she had been saving her lungs for this moment. She thrashed around in the water, much to the amusement of bystanders.
Their laughter faded as her shrieks became louder. Flushed with embarrassment, she tripped over in her hast to flee.
Oblivious to the calls concerning her welfare, or the strands of seaweed clung to her ankles and embedded in her tangled mass of hair. Allaying her fears had been tedious. It would be some time before the fear loosened its grip. Small acts of courage such as lingering by the shore allowed the ocean to coax her back within its reach.
She applied a thick layer of sunscreen, adjusting her hat. Already, she could feel the telltale signs on her shoulders. The expanse of the sea grounded her in the moment. Finding solace as each wave washed away a layer of tension. She began to breathe more easily as the salty spray reached her nostrils.
Leaning back, she observed the passing parade as the beach started to fill. Nearby, soft music drifted from a forgotten radio. She caught snippets of conversations. Families trudged along, dragging towels and fold-up chairs, the children sprinting on ahead with hopes of glimpsing the allusive dolphin. Even the parents, initially reluctant to come, found themselves searching the horizon, drawn by the promise.
Her train of thought was broken by a raucous screech. She squinted skyward as the gull crossed overhead, wings flapping. The bird touched down, balancing on one leg as if plotting the next move.
Her gaze was fixed firmly on the scavenger. She raised the remains of her sandwich to her lips, savouring the last bite. The gull was already airborne scoping out the next target. She was done with bullies.
She turned back to the ocean. The bulk carrier anchored off shore sounded its horn as if alerting the beachgoers to the dolphin's presence. A familiar, bottle-nosed silhouette broke the surface. A crowd gathered, mesmerized by the spirited antics. Phones caught every fleeting second. The dolphin arced in the air, performed a somersault before vanishing back into the water.
The woman gathered her belongings, paused to look back and smiled with peaceful knowing. Interactions with others were becoming simpler. A brief nod. A smile. A connection, however slight was beginning to form between herself and others.
Pot of Gold
By Lukas Dzambo
We rumbled along the dirt road, waves of coffee lapping the lip of my thermos as the truck's wheels navigated the worn-out gravel.
Jack jolted forward with a sharp gasp. "You're meant to drive around the potholes mate".
He shifted himself upright in the passenger seat, and flicked the music from 'FM' to 'disc', filling the ute cab with classic 80s folk.
My brother hated new music, "braindead hipster garbage" he was always calling it.
I had to be careful about which coffee shop to take him to whenever he visited me in town, god forbid somewhere that used a QR code for their menus.
"You know, you could also drive, I thought we were splitting the load."
I'd been driving for about five hours at this point, my arms were aching and my eyelids getting heavy.
We'd just spent the day up in the bush around the Myall Lakes, it's always been Jack's favourite spot.
We flew past fields of long dry grass, droning clicks of cicadas filling the late November air.
The air had that familiar sickly-sweet smell that always lingers after rain.
We'd just hit a few stormy passages on the highway before turning off onto this road.
In the distance, the storm clouds turned to a mist, and a thin rainbow began stretching across the sky.
"Would you look at that!" Jack stretched his arm across me and pointed to the stroke of colour painted in the sky.
"Yeah, think that means we have good luck or something?"
"Pretty sure that's only when it's a double," Jack tapped me with his elbow.
"Oh right, that sucks ..."
"Don't worry, there should still be a pot of gold," he grinned.
"Well of course, but you have to get past the leprechaun of course."
"True, probably not worth the hassle."
We kept driving for a few minutes, letting the windows down to enjoy the breeze as the sun sank closer to the horizon.
The wind swept through the car, carrying little bits of dandelion and the faint scent of a faraway bushfire.
"You know, I think the whole pot of gold thing is more of a metaphor ... Like it's a bit of a subjective pot, beauty in the eye of the beholder or some crap."
He was resting his arm against the door, propping up his chin like one of those ancient Greek dudes ... what a moron, I thought to myself.
"What are you on about Jack, there's not an actual end of the rainbow," I chuckled back to him.
"How do you know? Have you ACTUALLY checked, or are you just surrendering to your boring grey world."
He said this with a weird sincerity, it felt like I may have actually struck a nerve.
We shot a couple jabs back and forth and returned to our mutual silence, meditation among the soft chorus of the bush, with the occasional 'bang' of the truck-bed pulling us back up.
Part of what Jack insisted on kept nagging at me, his childlike sincerity seemed to dig its way into my heart, like one those cartoon worms in kids' books that make a home out of some poor lad's apple.
Maybe I had become cynical, maybe part of me was chipped away on the concrete corridors of the city, maybe I had lost some colour from my eye.
Damnit Jack.
I swung my ute around, dodging some shallow puddles and tree roots.
By the time I reached the treeline the sun had started its final stretch, eclipsed by the rolling hills in the distance. I didn't have much time.
Between the trees I found a narrow bush path, the grass was trodden down, painting a faint line through the brush.
I kept trudging through, checking the darkening sky every few minutes to make sure I was staying the course.
I came across a small creek; it bubbled across the ground and ran away down the hill.
I followed along until it began to widen, eventually becoming a decent sized pond, flanked by a rocky bank on either side.
I don't know what I had hoped to find, part of me wanted to find Jack sitting out on the shore, chucking handfuls of pebbles across the still water like we used to do as kids.
The sun fell below the mountain, and the rainbow faded into the faint stars.
I sat myself on a nest of roots and caught my breath.
Out here the only noise was my thoughts, and the soft babble of the creek.
Jack and I used to spend hours playing in streams, chasing the next big adventure as we barrelled through nature's playground.
I didn't even feel it start, but tears began to roll down my face, I realised this was the first time I've felt close to my brother since we lost him.
Maybe I've found my pot of gold.
Semaphore
By Karen Whitelaw
Years before, Ramit's grandmother had the insight to snap up an old World War III fort when they were decommissioned, ignoring the scoffing neighbours in their glass mansions overlooking the ocean.
It wasn't long before those same neighbours came fighting through the wind and storms to his grandmother's steel door, hammering to be let into the safety of the underground rooms. Later, Ramit's family would help them pick around the twisted steel beams and shards of glass, and pack whatever was salvageable. It was never much. A coffee tamper. An antique desk. A robotic window cleaner. Nothing you'd choose to take on a new life. Those neighbours were gone long before I came.
Ramit and I have chickens, two goats, and grow spinach, tomatoes, lettuce and beans on the roof, which we swap at the Collectives with people who have thumbs with different colours to ours. I met Ramit after my family bought passage on an old Sydney ferry taking people from our drowning overcrowded city to a sanctuary settlement on the south coast. The sea was rough. To amuse my eight-year-old sister I fashioned two flags out of chopsticks and my father's blue-checked handkerchiefs. The captain's mate taught her semaphore. To impress me, I think. My mother was seasick, although I suspected, at my hormone-laden age of 15, when everything looked like sex, that there was another reason she spewed the tiny amount of food she was allotted over the side. I never got to find out. After 12 days we reached the promised land. Twenty men with shotguns were lined up along the pier to meet us.
'We've got too many refugees,' the man in black said. 'Move on.'
Over the loudhailer the captain begged the settlers to let us disembark. Couldn't they see the black clouds on the horizon? We'd leave straight after the storm. For an answer, all 20 men aimed their shotguns at the people squashed on the deck, not having the money for an inside ticket. We heard them bashing on the doors, screaming to be let in. Inside, Gemma and I clung to Dad.
Our captain looked for a landing along the coast. The cliffs were high and the frequent gales had stripped all the sand off the beaches, leaving sharp jagged rocks. The storm hit around midnight. The ferry lurched and bucked. A fierce wind forced rain through the cracks in the shutters, drenching us. The word 'cyclone' gushed through the cabin like running water. Gemma, clutching her flags, frantically signalled SOS as if someone would help. She wouldn't stop, even when I lassoed her waist and pulled her close.
Again and again, we felt the ferry lever over the tip of huge waves. Heard the timbers creak sickeningly. With one arm around Gemma, I, gripping the timber seat, dreading the moment we'd go into freefall. Screaming as the ferry crashed nose-first into the trough, crying out as we slammed painfully into timber and metal and other sprawling bony bodies. Convinced each time would be our last. Then the waves came so close together the ferry had no time to straighten up. The sea devoured us.
Ramit and his father found the survivors on the rock ledge below the fort the next morning. Five of us, all shivering among the dead bodies, silent, blank eyes staring out at the deceptively calm sea. My mother, father and sister were not there. I have not given up on finding them. Whenever Ramit's family heard of a body washed up along the coast we'd pack a bag with food, slip a knife into our belts, and make the journey.
There's just Ramit and me left now, and he won't come anymore. He says after ten years there'd be no one to find. Don't think he's mean. He's pragmatic. I am, too. Usually.
Every month at the Collectives, I'm scanning the crowd for a shock of red hair, a thin balding man with a slight stoop, a child with my mother's face, and when I see them my heart flips and I rush forward. The person turns at my touch but it's never them. One look at my stricken face and these strangers always have a kind hand for my shoulder; everyone is searching for someone. My name is all I have left and I give it freely.
Ramit and I sleep in the old signal room. Once he found a rusty spring bed base in a derelict hotel near the beach. We scrubbed it with sand and relaced it with fencing wire we swapped for eggs at a Collective.
We started padding his grandmother's old mattress with chicken feathers until some scavengers climbed through the lookout one night and stole our previous brood of chickens. That's the trouble with having to spend so much time underground; you don't see what's happening up top. But at least you escape the heat and the storms and the marauding gangs. Mostly. It's a balancing act between what's worse and worse.
Early one morning I'm in the lookout checking the tide. The sea has been rough for weeks and we need to supplement our salted fish stocks before we hunker in against the summer heat. I see a small ferry speeding across the bay. I call Ramit and he's here immediately. We watch until we're sure it's coming for us. The chickens scrabble around our feet, squawking to be released for the day. The goats butt our legs. We herd them back into the tunnel.
Before I lock us in, I take one last look. I can make out a woman standing on the bow.
She's waving two blue-checked flags.
The tree
By Fred Koegelenberg
I pressed my back against the old, peeling tree as the wind caressed my hair. I had lain beneath that tree through multiple sunsets, looking to the sky for clues, clues to anything.
The steaming sun brushed my burnt skin as I continued to wail. I was too weak to walk, and there was no one for miles. Life was draining from me as more blood spilled from my wound.
I used to live in a house close to where I was now. It had beautiful plants growing from each corner and intricately designed wooden furnishings. But the best part was life, how my ears filled with the sound of family laughing. And my dad, oh my dad, how he showed me why I should smile every day. I don't know if fate hated him or if God was against him, but one day, he never woke up.
Life felt bleak after that, yet the sun still shone. My mother couldn't bear it; they were inseparable, and after that numb day, guilt poured her a drink. Gosh, how much I loved them both. She wasn't as strong as my dad. I wish I could've helped before she left, too. After that, life just kept going. Nothing stopped. People felt pity, but that didn't make time slow down. A blur filled my vision, maybe from pain or from my tears. Either way, I had to get back on my feet.
I went to three different foster homes before I started running. Most weeks I would pack a bag and go on another adventure. That house was the last of my memories, and I couldn't forget it. Cars would always hurl down the road near my deserted home whenever I got there, but every second I stepped foot in that place was worth it.
I just wanted to live, and that house had helped me before. The memories held a sense of hope that this wasn't real - because at that time, it couldn't have been. It was too quick, like a dream you couldn't stay in because you needed to wake up.
Most of the time, when I was at my rustic-looking house, I would search every dusted room, having a gut feeling that maybe it was just a game and I had to find them. But it wasn't. It never was. Being taken again and again felt like being ripped from the most important organs keeping me alive.
I just wanted life back. I wanted them to live with me and die with me. I was only ten when everything happened, and things still didn't fully make sense. What was I meant to do? When I finally tried to live without running from everything, my foster parents were the Morrisons. They were in their 40s to 50s, and smoked a lot. Yet that didn't seem to matter because I knew they didn't want to tear me apart straight away. They cared for me. On weekends, they used to drive me to my old home and let me run my fingers along the corridors, never pushing me too far, finally letting me take my time.
They showed me that even when time is going fast, you can make it slow. I felt like I could trust again, and soon, I did. As the years went on, the more their lungs consumed smoke, until they couldn't stop coughing. It scared me - the thought that every year I spent resting instead of running might disappear as their tough voices grew scratchier. Their bodies seemed thinner, bonier, frail-looking with their pale grey skin. I knew they had stopped taking precautions ages ago, and I could see them becoming absent-minded. Now I just wish I had talked to them sooner.
I remember how they cared about my obsession with the past and helped slower than time ticked. I loved them for that - for their kindness that helped my heart forgive. I loved them...
One week, after years had passed with them, I wanted to look back at my house, knowing it would open a wound. But back then, I could slowly patch it up. Back then, I had time to resolve my problems. So we went. The house looked like it had been untouched for ages, webs covering every corner except my heart. That's when one mistake destroyed everything.
Mrs Morrison asked me to light her new cigarette as we sat on the porch. I swear, I didn't realise how badly my hands trembled as I looked behind her. A tree, my tree, stood behind her. The very tree where we spread my parents' ashes.I wasn't ready to come back. I never should've.
I didn't even realise the lighter had fallen until a flame crawled up my shoes. But it was too late. The house that had held me together was now being torn apart because I couldn't focus on what was in front of me.
The Morrisons tried to help, but the fire spread too quickly, and smoke engulfed them - presumably killing them. My legs couldn't move back then, unlike my confused tears. Without thinking, I ran toward my old, dying tree and lay underneath it.
And now, here I am, lying on the soft soil next to my mother and father. The blood on my legs is finally starting to dry. But I know this was all my fault - everything. I had a second chance, and now everything is gone except this old, decaying oak tree. My life isn't liveable unless someone finds me now, but I'm not even sure I want that.
The people in my life who cared about me and showed me kindness are gone, and now I stand between life and death. I know I was meant to die, either today, yesterday, or many years ago. I was meant to pass.
Yet I know it's inevitable. I know I should survive - for them.
Bitter Sweet
By Brenda Proudfoot
Friday
There she goes again, wittering on at Mavis like she's some kind of imbecile. I've told you before, haven't I, how Diane uses that ridiculous baby voice whenever she speaks to the residents: I see you've eaten all your vegies, Mavis. What a good girl. Would you like to join in this afternoon's sing-song? It's all your old favourites . . .'Pack up your Troubles', 'The Road to Gundagai' ...
Oh, for heaven's sake! The girl doesn't realise we were young women during the '50s and '60s, not during the First World War. Oh, look out, she's coming my way.
Would you like to join us, Anne? "No, thank you, Diane. I'm heading to my room to finish this month's novel for book club."
Did you see the look on her face? Like anyone still reads books!
What's that? I shouldn't be so unkind? You're right, I suppose. It's just that Diane has no idea what kind of lives we've led.
Take Mavis, for example. Until she had that stroke last year, she was as sharp as a tack. Did you know she was a high school principal for almost 20 years? She had to resign when she got married, but after the rules changed in the 1960s, she returned to teaching and rose to the top of the ranks.
Tuesday
I'm not up to much today. Mavis was very poorly yesterday and passed away early this morning. I can't tell you how much I'll miss her. We were partners in crime. There aren't too many people in here who take an interest in the outside world. Mavis had a wonderful sense of humour, and whenever living here got me down, having a laugh with her cheered me up no end.
Wednesday
I wasn't keen on this month's story. It was about a writer and his rescue dogs. The mischief those dogs got up to! I wouldn't have put up with them for a week! Still, book club's the highlight of my month. It's open to anyone who lives in the village, not just the nursing home residents.
Sunday
Andrew called in. He couldn't stay long because Jess wants to take the girls to the ocean baths. I'm so proud of our boy. He has a smile or a friendly word for everyone.
Thursday
It was Mavis's funeral today. It was like a military manoeuvre trying to load us oldies into the minibus. It's not easy for us to manage the step. Harry has the best of it - they load him in, wheelchair and all. It was like one of those ridiculous maths problems: If there are eight nursing home residents including a man in a wheelchair, and one driver, how many walkers can you fit into a minibus? The funeral was sad. It was quite clear the celebrant knew nothing about Mavis' life or personality. Apart from her niece and her family and a couple of people from church, we were the only ones there.
Friday
I'm feeling down in the dumps. I know you'd do your best to cheer me up if you were here. We always tried to see the funny side of life, didn't we. Especially when times were tough. I remember having a laugh with Andrew at Centrelink. We were waiting in the queue to apply for a government funeral benefit. Your husband has died. Collect $200. It was so bizarre, it made us laugh.
Sometimes, I think life is a lottery. Some of the loveliest people I've known have been snatched away in their prime, whereas others live on and on. There's no rhyme or reason to it as far as I can see. I think Charles Darwin was on the right track. It's all down to random selection.
Sunday
Diane's on duty today. She's brought in her dog, Monty, to show the residents. He's one of those sausage dogs. I've never had much time for lapdogs. We always had working dogs, didn't we. We couldn't have managed the farm without our kelpies.
Oh, no. There she goes again in her ridiculous baby voice. She's gooing and gaaing at that dog like you might to a six-week-old baby! I have to say, though, he's a lovely dog - so calm and cuddly. He's curled up on Harry's lap and every now and then, he lifts his head and looks at Harry with his big brown eyes. There's something special about eyes. When our kelpies looked up at us, it was as if they could read our minds. Diane's doing the rounds of the residents. She's one of the better carers if I'm honest. She takes time to talk to each of us. She's showing everyone something on her phone. Several people have smiled or laughed out loud. She's heading over my way. It must be a good joke as it seems to appeal to everyone even those who hardly ever smile.
Hi Anne, would you like to see a photo of Monty in a dog race?
I smile obligingly and she holds the phone so that I can see the photo. And there's Monty bounding through the air, full of joy and youthful exuberance. I feel a surge of love and gratitude - not for the dog but for you, my darling. Do you remember how you stood at the altar waiting for me to walk up the aisle? Then you turned and looked at me. I've never forgotten the joy I felt when I saw my love reflected in your eyes.
Clarity
By Andrew P.J. McMahon
Since Detective Katie Ross moved to Newy, she'd loved the foreshore run. At sunrise, sunset, and everywhere in between. Katie wasn't alone; all of Newcastle seemed to be out. Most days she shared the path with walkers and surfers taking in the salt breeze, but today she ran because she was angry. Frustrated and haunted by her past, she felt a familiar darkness creeping in.
Compared to the Blue Mountains' misty haze and fire-ravaged heat, Newy won every time. She missed the mountains' views and unrivalled trails, but outwitting a serial killer in the wilderness demanded a change of scenery. That case brought Katie to Newy, and she fell in love with its coastal grit.
The afternoon was spectacular, but the air felt heavy. As she approached Carrington, the chirping of waking bats filled her ears and nose. To the north, the skies were clear, but to the west, a gigantic thunderstorm was rapidly rolling in. As Katie passed the fish markets, she looked toward the silhouette of Stockton and felt a familiar, cold frustration. Ten kilometers due north, as the crow flies, was where they found Jane, deep in the Stockton sand dunes. The problem with dunes is that they shift; they swallow evidence. Katie had no footprints, no loose fibers. Nothing. All she had was a victim in her early 20s with what would have been rich, flowing red hair. The only distinguishing features were a tattoos of all sizes, that had, so far, provided no clue to her identity.
Katie's Jane Doe was destined to become another unsolved mystery in the Newcastle Herald archives if they didn't get a breakthrough soon. It felt like a dead end, and for Katie, that was where the darkness lived. The thought made her stomach tighten. Jane deserved better. When Katie felt like this, seething, it was her running shoes that paid the price. She was metronomically pounding her way through Honeysuckle now, dodging pub patrons scurrying for cover. The first drops of rain sounded big, almost heavy, as they exploded on the pavement. Katie quickened her pace, recalculating her route in an instant. She wouldn't make the beach. She aimed for the shelter of Queens Wharf.
Suddenly, the world lit up with a gigantic lightning strike, followed by a thunderclap that shook her chest. Katie counted the seconds. "One mississippi, two mississippi... boom." The storm would envelope her soon.
Her breathing was hard, but the footpath was clear; no one else was silly enough to be out in this. The pine trees near Scratchleys were heaving as she flew past. Then, the sky opened. In an instant, the rain was torrential, and Katie, drenched to the bone, ducked undercover at the Queens Wharf terminal. The sky was now midnight black. As the rain pelted the metal roof, the rhythmic drum-drum-drum triggered something deep and dark. Katie closed her eyes and was suddenly back in that tin shed in the Megalong Valley. She could smell the rust and the damp earth. She was tied up, staring down the person she had trusted with her life, the man who had betrayed her. Katie snapped her eyes open, her heart racing.
"I'm in Newy now," she muttered, her voice lost in the roar of the wind. "You're safe. He is gone."
Seeking distance from the sheltering crowd, she noticed a stairwell across the way. She scooted through the doorway as the rain pelted sideways, the droplets literally bruising her face. She shook off the water and slowly ascended the stairs. At the top was a room looking out across the harbour. Graffiti decorated every inch of the walls, a coded welcome to the tourists who usually flocked here for the view. Every color of the rainbow captured slogans and tags, a foreign language known only to the writers.
The room was dim, but as Katie turned to leave, a streak of light from a distant break in the clouds hit the wall near the doorway.
She froze. There, written in a dark, brownish-red at eye level, was a symbol. It was two snakes interwoven around a hammer, sitting on top of a rising sun. Katie gasped, her detective's brain snapping into focus. She had seen this before. It was on Jane's left shoulder blade, the same size and colour. Katie's hands shook as she snapped a photo. She frantically scoured the rest of the room. Lower down, under the window overlooking the harbour, she saw more writing in that same reddish pen: "Evie loves Daz" and "Newy Sunrise Crew Forever".
She punched in a number, her eyes never leaving the wall. "Jenny, it's Katie. I just sent you a picture. Tell me it is what I think it is." She waited, her breath held. "Exactly. I found it in the lookout room at Queens Wharf. Get forensics here immediately and some probies to seal this off. Don't let anyone near these walls."
As Katie hung up, she looked through the window, framing the view exactly like the camera lens had moments before. The storm had passed as quickly as it had arrived. The sunset was gleaming over the water, and the darkness was lifting. The Stockton ferry was making its way toward her, its silhouette sharp against the clearing horizon. For the first time in months, Katie felt a spark of genuine vigour. The "Jane" in the dunes finally had a name: Evie. The storm had passed through her and left something behind. Clarity. As she looked toward the distant Stockton sands, she knew right then she would find the rest of the Crew. She would find Evie's killer.
Small town talk
By Rhonda Mackey
"Look Mummy, pretty circle in the sky."
Gilly had seen the rainbow and couldn't help but smile in spite of the deep-seated worry swilling in her gut.
"That's a rainbow Alex. It means that good things will happen."
Checking the fuel gauge, she murmured quietly to herself; lord knows we could use some good luck for a change. And as much as she was determined not to, she couldn't help but think back on recent events. That knock on the door late at night and the policeman standing with her mother.
Two steps in, two sentences spoken, and her body had sunk to the floor. She looked back over her shoulder to the white curls poking out from the edge of the fluffy pink blanket covering her daughter as she slept on the back seat. Her hand clung to Alex's foot which lay curled under his bottom.
Lotty seemed to draw comfort from the physical presence of her brother and had been for months now, the shadow he couldn't shake. Gilly smiled, thinking how she'd been the same with her brother, until he started to become aware that having a little sister hanging off him was a bit off in the eyes of his mates. But she'd not had to deal with the sense of fear and abandonment that her two could sense rather than speak of.
They were still too young to understand death. But then thought Gilly, who does? Certainly not her. Her fuel was getting low and she wondered if she was doing the right thing. She just needed to get away and think.
Things at home were closing in on her. The recent argument with her father.
"You've let the town down, Gilly. They raised that money for you and what do you go and do. You don't really know this bloke. His history with women, what if he's not who you think he is?"
Gilly felt so mixed up inside when she'd looked at her father's face. The tears in his eyes just made her feel sick. And what if he was right and all her instincts were wrong?
But when she was with Simon it didn't feel wrong. She'd watched him closely with the kids; he just seemed to love them - and it wasn't forced - she knew, in the way every mother knows if there is anything off, her maternal radar would roar.
Especially since the kids were both so young, and vulnerable. She'll never forget how much comfort they all got over those next few, awful weeks after the accident, she and the kids, snuggled together in her bed at night. How she'd kept their father's pyjama top folded under her pillow, taking it out when alone and just holding it up to her face. Breathing him in. Bringing him back - if only for as long as his smell lingered. And when she felt sad, but in control, she knew the kids settled. Lotty's crying eased off and Alex's frantic running to the door every time someone knocked - making sure he greeted them with the news. "My Daddy's dead."
He didn't really know what dead meant, but he knew that like show and tell at preschool, it was big news. Gilly worried about his lack of understanding, but it kind of protected him from what she felt; her grief, spiralling between despair and anxiety.
Now she had that awful row with her father simmering in her mind.
The money the town raised at the country dance had been spent on the kids. It wasn't a fortune, but it did pay for their new clothes and a three-wheel trainer bike for Alex. So .... did that give the good women of the town's CWA the right to judge her? She wondered exactly what had been said, that had made her father so upset. He'd yelled at her and that really hurt. Seeing that, his face had softened. "You'll be alright on your own, Gilly. Lots of women in town have raised their kids alone."
"Oh great....so you want me to be like Mrs Kincade? Who always has a red nose and wobbles on her Mary Janes each morning after a night with the sweet sherry? That your idea of widowhood and clean country living Dad?"
"She does a lot for this town Gilly. Every School of Arts event, she's there. And she did lots of cooking for your fundraiser."
"And that's your secret to real happiness is it, Dad? Loneliness and lamingtons? Well, I'm sorry. Times are changing - not everyone is happy doing those things. I didn't do them before. And now...... I don't know yet what I want. But it isn't that."
Looking back through the rearview mirror she could see the faint colours of the rainbow receding. Soon nothing would remain of that spectrum of promise. Like all hopes and dreams of her previous married life. If going out to a weekend barbecue could in one fatal minute of a driver's miscalculation, lead to death, and mean that a young husband and father would never return home, how could she possibly make plans for the future?
Life was a lottery. She wasn't a gambler, but she did know one sure thing: nothing was more important to her than those two in the back seat, now curled up together, bent knees and legs entangled, heads touching, blissful sleep dissolving all worry.
She would do whatever she had to - keeping them safe and loved ... always.
Trapped
By Peter Gittins
Shuffling quietly along the road he glanced at the fading streetlamp that cast a dim shadow on the rockface below.
He took a final drag on his cigarette - a long, slow, deliberate draw - before stubbing it on the ground with a shoe worn with age and barely fit for purpose.
His clothes had seen better days, too. A green hoodie covered his frail upper body, and his oversized black pants bore the scars of a hard life on the street. His dark and weathered face, partially covered by a black beanie, was well known despite him making every effort to hide it over many years.
He turned around one last time to make sure he was not being followed, placed his grubby hands on the shopping cart, and squeezed into the thick undergrowth near the side of the road.
Dark storm clouds were assembling on the horizon and the claps of thunder in the distance convinced him that he needed to move quickly.
He jammed his cart into a small crevice to protect it from the impending storm, unwrapped a brown tarpaulin, grabbed a frayed sleeping bag, torch and water bottle and continued up the hill.
The familiar path through the bush was narrow and hazardous. Roots grew close to the surface and recent rain had made everything wet and slippery.
When he finally reached his destination, he darted through the open doorway and made it to the far wall of the now derelict building just as the sky opened.
He threw his kit onto the floor and then proceeded to sweep the floor clean with a ragged cloth that he always carried with him.
Had he not been a trapped by the prison of his memories he may well have taken the time to admire the astonishing view over the Pacific Ocean and the mansions he saw from the decayed window frame. But that was not his reality and had not been so for such a long time.
Feeling safe and warm despite the pelting rain and cold autumn breeze, he peered at the plethora of graffiti sprayed on the walls. Some new, some old, some carrying faded political messages and some with the tags of neighbourhood kids who frequented the skatepark below.
These images meant nothing to him, but they were a distraction at least and gave him something to briefly focus on. A boom of thunder and streak of sheet lightning shattered his thoughts. He was suddenly back in a field wading through a sodden rice paddy, knee deep in tepid water with both arms raised carrying a rifle above his head.
His body ached from three days of toil in the hot, unforgiving, jungle, but he knew he had to press forward.
Barely twenty years old he found it hard to understand why he was there, but he felt proud to be alongside his mates who zigzagged silently behind him.
They inched forward, sweat mixing with naked fear, and headed for the designated landing zone that was marked out by a bright flare just ten metres ahead.
The whirl of the chopper was almost lost amongst the loud pop of bullets that thudded into the small bank close behind.
With one final, desperate dash he dodged another flurry of enemy fire and scrambled onto the floor of the chopper with his feet resting perilously on the landing skid bar. His mates jumped in behind, glad to be getting out of the hell that had unfolded below. As the chopper climbed into the sky, Bluey looked across at him. His fear was now replaced by relief, and all six of them were thankful that no one was coming home in a body bag.
Back in Saigon, Thuy waited for him in a small apartment off Rue Catinat just as she had done since they first met nine months ago. Theirs was a love grounded in war and a relationship that crossed cultures and the crazy politics of the time.
When his tour was over, he promised her he would come back. 'Just give me time,' he said. After one final embrace and fighting back tears, he walked out the door.
He must have slept as the sun was now peeking over the horizon. It was time to go, however, because the school kids would soon be coming just as they did every morning.
Coke cans, sandwich wrappers, and strips of foil lay scattered on the floor as evidence of their last visit and reminded him of the need to avoid contact with them because contact inevitably meant trouble.
Reaching into his jacket, he clutched a wrinkled piece of paper buried deep inside the pocket. The paper was old and faded, and the writing was barely visible. But it was all he had to remind him of her - a letter from Bluey saying that Thuy had been killed in a blast outside the Hotel Continental.
She had been coming back from the market as she did every morning, walking past the service personnel who gathered on the pavement drinking their morning coffee when the bomb exploded.
In an instant, Thuy had become just one more of the many civilian casualties of the conflict - the collateral damage of war they called it.
Today would have been her birthday, and she was his only thought as he trudged back down the hill with a cigarette drooped in his mouth and a faint tear falling onto his long, grey beard.
Picture Perfect
By Brett Thomas
One sixtieth of a second. Remarkable that such a speck of time could generate so much gravity. My hobby was photography, to capture places and people at a precise moment, one sixtieth of it. Some of those moments are forgotten. Others become artefacts. This one is suspended between the two.
I took the picture down from the shelf. My wife had it framed after I won the annual photography prize in the local newspaper, the Newcastle Herald. Despite the sadly diminishing relevance of so-called legacy media, there was kudos in having one's photo printed on the front page of the edition announcing the winner. It portrayed what's special about our city, said the paper.
We liked it when friends visited and initiated discussions about the photo as it beamed from the family room bookshelf.
What to do with it now. My wife said I should leave it there and be done with it. Have the conversations, if and when they emerge. It's a great photo, she said. A beach, a swimmer, a dolphin, a ship in the background. It captures the mysterious beauty of a place that for most Australians conjures images that are gritty, dusty and grey. Of factories, coal trains, and uncomplicated suburbia. This photo said otherwise.
I knew she was right. Her pragmatic female perspective, unburdened by my befuddled circumspection, should have settled the matter. It is a good photo. People will want to discuss it over dinner, over drinks. Why fear the discussion descending into sullen reflection?
You're not responsible, she said. It's worthy of admiration regardless of what happened. And yet, I found the prospect of those conversations confronting. The newspaper report said he saw the photograph and decided to go there for a swim. His wife said he loved to swim, several times a week, and would randomly choose places, based upon not much more than a photo in the newspaper. He was 52. Fit as a fiddle, according to the newspaper. I never understood what that meant. He had so much to live for. Of course. Trite platitudes surround tragic events. It's an odd combination.
Two kids. A teacher. A volunteer firefighter. A member of an over 35s football team. A coach. Played in a band back in the day. Well known, it seems.
The photograph, in its frame, on the shelf, will trigger these conversations. About the innocence of impulse. About degrees of separation. Melancholy will ripple softly across the room. A shark attack is a drama with its own postcode. The media goes about its job stoking the fires of our fears, and we do the rest. It's always an attack, random and unprovoked. The shark is the villain, and we are the victims. But then again, the ocean is their backyard. We are the invaders. He accepted the danger. It's just bad luck. Opinions will continue to unfurl in muted conflict. Do I need that every time someone visits? The phone rang. It was my brother.
"Wasn't that your photo they're talking about. The place where that guy was attacked by the shark yesterday?" "Yep."
"Wow. That must be weird. For you."
"Not really," I lied. "It's just chance. You know ... fame and misfortune." I made that up. I thought it sounded good. I regretted it immediately. "Whatever. The missus reckons it must be weird." "Yeah. I suppose..."
"Anyway, we'll be over tonight. 6pm OK? We'll bring wine." "Sure. See you then."
For more of that conversation, no doubt. Maybe not so much if I remove the photo. Put it somewhere else. Somewhere only I can see it. That'd work. I took a tissue, cleaned the frame, and laid the photo on my lap. It wasn't my favourite photo. A bit of a clich in a way. The stereotypical Novocastrian imagery was picture perfect. I'd been quite happy for people to see it, to comment upon its emblematic rendering. Now that it represented so much more than that, I didn't want anyone to see it. My wife walked past.
"What are you going to do with it?" she asked. She understood my apprehension, but thought it a cop out. She valued honesty, hard discussions, to set the controls for the heart of the matter. I was more guarded. Sensitive. She'd call it precious. "I think I might put it in the study." She knew why. "It's your photo," she grumbled.
The phone rang again. It was a reporter from the Newcastle Herald.
"I hope you don't mind. I got your number from the file. I thought maybe you have some thoughts on what happened yesterday. The man. The shark attack. It was your photo wasn't it, that led him to the place?"
"I have no thoughts," I said. "It was terrible. Just so unfortunate. I feel for his family."
I'm sure I'd said these things before, but never had they meant less than now. I never knew him. It was just a photo. But I didn't say that. I wasn't honest. The reporter prodded and I kept saying how I was sorry for their loss. The discussion went nowhere. If I said what I really thought, the newspaper wouldn't print it. Or maybe it would. Then I'd be the villain. No doubt my dour responses will be shaped into a melodramatic sentence reinforcing the gloom of it all.
I carried the photo into the study, sat in my chair, and placed it on the desk, so it couldn't be seen from the doorway. Nobody would ever see it. Except for me. I can have those conversations now, about fate, about choice, with myself.
My phone rang. I didn't answer.
Whisper Back
By MJ Meagher
The garage door rolled up to reveal oppressive grey clouds, hanging low and matching my melancholic mood. The dog pulled at the lead. My daughter kicked her legs in the pram restlessly. She craned her neck to look up at me, her blonde hair messy, puffer-jacket zipped over her pyjamas.
"Park, park," she said, rocking back and forth. Thank God for her, I thought, heart aching. I always woke in a low mood. A toddler dragging me from bed had been my rescue, my only remedy.
My wife loved and guided me but there was something about the simple, boundless love of a three-year-old that reached deeper into my heart than I thought possible.
"Yep. Park," I replied. I pushed the pram outside and into the pre-dawn gloom. It rolled quietly over the pavement, bumping at uneven cracks, fading in and out of the puddles of light cast by the streetlamps.
A winter breeze blew down Brooks Street, stinging my cheeks but smelling fresh. We walked slowly, stopping for the dog to pee, or for my daughter to pick a flower, and slowly made our way towards Centennial Park. I wondered if he was there.
The last few months, Lily had been waking early, before five o'clock. We fought it for a while, trying to re-settle her and cling to a normal adult routine. But with my wife working evening shifts and needing the sleep-in, we eventually relented control to our little master. I accepted the early morning shift. Trying to keep the house quiet, I would get up with Lily, cram snacks into the pram, and make for Centennial Park early.
It was nice to have the playframes to ourselves. Like me, Lily didn't mind playing in her own company. The dog got a run-around; I'd watch the sun come up and get some time with my daughter before work.
But we didn't quite have the park to ourselves. Every morning, a man would be on the opposite side of the park, under one of the older trees. He didn't seem to notice us at all. I'd be on the park bench, one eye on Lily, one on the dog, and would see him pull up. His ute would rumble to a stop, he would get out, garish in a high-vis vest, and stand under the same tree. He seemed lost in his own thoughts. Often, he'd sit on the ground, other times he would lean on the trunk, or absent-mindedly pluck at leaves and woodchips. After a few minutes, he would get back into his ute and drive off to work.
He was always a hundred metres away, and we never spoke but he was an oddly comforting presence. Maybe it was my own obsessive personality, but I'd enjoyed the rhythm of seeing him each morning.
Today, we'd been moving more slowly than usual and I felt an inexplicable pressure to get to the park, an urge to not miss him. I hurried across Dawson Street, rattling Lily's pram over the cracked bitumen and under the fig trees to enter the park.
Looking across, I could see him under the same old, gnarled tree. He was leaning against the trunk, his forehead against a low-lying branch. He had a bright orange worker's jacket on today, with the hood up. Quite unexpectedly, my dog impulsively pulled away, and I lost hold of the lead.
He bolted in a line towards the man. I called out, but he didn't obey. I jogged to catch up, pushing the pram roughly over the grass but couldn't beat the dog to the tree. He sniffed and licked at the man's feet.
"Sorry, mate," I called out, breathless as I jogged to a stop. "Had him on the lead but ... sorry ..." The man didn't look up but scratched the dog between the ears.
"All good, mate, all good," came the slow, hoarse reply. He had his head downcast, the hood obscuring his face. Only a pointed, stubbled chin was visible. An awkward silence fell on me but the man seemed comfortable with it, patiently patting the dog's flank. After a couple of moments, Lily spoke up from the pram.
"Why were you talking to the tree?" she asked plainly. Embarrassed, I placed a hand on her head. "Ssshhh darling, leave him alone," I implored her. "Sorry, mate, don't mean to be rude ... she didn't mean ..."
The man looked up, first at Lily with a kind smile, then at me. He was unshaven with short hair, his eyes brown. He was younger than I'd thought; a similar age to me. His chin quivered a little as he looked at us.
"Must be going mad, love," he said to Lily with a shrug. His laugh was a lie and his eyes swam in grief. But he stretched a smile across his face for me anyway.
"Beautiful girl you've got, mate."
He opened his mouth as if to say something else but then closed it again. He turned, ducking under the branch to walk away, his fingertips lingering on the rough bark briefly before he trudged to his ute. And it seemed to me that the tree was left lonely, gazing up at the sky. Its limbs outstretched in a desperate, unrequited embrace of the heavens. The spindly branches, which in its youth must have been graced by headily-scented flowers and held nests with chicks chirping in the morning sun, were now barren and skeletal under the cold winter sky. Without warning, a sudden gust swept down from the west, buffeting the tree and I. The dog barked madly at first but then cowered behind me, whining as the wind rustled through the branches. It sounded for a moment as if the tree had whispered something back but, looking around, I saw that the man had already gone.
The Phone
By Dan Shushko
The sun hung low, bleeding orange light across the crowded Bar Beach promenade. Luke sat at a small, worn table outside the caf. The air was thick with heat, tangled with the crash of waves.
He sipped his coffee, its warmth a fleeting escape from the weight of his day. The office had been chaotic, his email chiming with demands. His job carried secrets and confidentiality, the kind that gnawed at him and got under his skin. Just a few minutes before driving back into the grind. But out here on the edge of the ocean it felt like there was just a moment of peace.
Luke leaned back in his chair and looked towards the horizon. Two dogs walking past started barking at each other. The shrill noise brought him back to where he was. That's when he noticed a phone on the table across from him. He glanced around. No one was looking his way. Luke picked it up. It was a black iPhone, scuffed as if it had been dropped too many times. The case was simple, no marks of ownership. Luke noticed a slip of paper tucked into the case. A scrap of paper which had, handwritten in smudged ink, PIN: 7462. Call: 0432648964. Then four words - Tomato, potato, strawberry, lime.
Luke looked around again for the owner. He'd hand it in to the caf. It wasn't his problem, but something stopped him. Torn between curiosity and caution, his thumb hovered over the screen. What was the harm in dialling the number? He'd be a good Samaritan and find the owner. He entered the pin, dialled the number. It rang twice before a deep voice answered. "Who's this?"
Luke hesitated. "I found your phone." The voice on the other end paused, then spoke. "We wondered if you'd pick it up. Tell me the words." "What?" "The code," the voice growled. "What's the four word code?" Luke glanced at the paper. "Tomato, potato, strawberry, lime," the words tasting foreign in his mouth.
"Good," the voice said. "Now listen carefully. I need you to take the phone to a place by the harbour. I'll text you the address."
Luke's throat tightened. "What's going on?" The voice didn't hesitate. "It doesn't matter. Just do as I say. Take the phone to the address and he doesn't get hurt."
"Who's he?" Spat out Luke. "You've got an hour. Tick-tock." Before Luke could respond, the line went dead. The caf noises seemed muffled now. Luke stared at the phone. A text arrived with the address. He knew the suburb by the harbour. It was full of half-abandoned warehouses and houses that didn't belong. He could feel the sweat on his back. He shouldn't get involved. He should walk away. Something got the better of him. He kept wondering about 'him'.
Luke put the phone in his pocket and left the caf. The drive wasn't long, but felt endless. Red lights stretched time. Luke blasted the air conditioning, cold against his face, but it didn't help. His thoughts churned. Luke parked a block away, the eerie silence amplifying his unease. The harbour gleamed, the blue water now unsettling instead of calm. He gripped the phone, his hands clammy despite the warmth outside.
The warehouse loomed ahead, ugly and decaying. Weeds clawed at the edges. The door hung open and Luke stepped inside. The walls had graffiti layered onto graffiti and were barely still standing. The beams were rusted and the air smelled of dust and metal. Then, he heard footsteps. The figure stepped out of the shadows-tall, imposing. His face was hard, unreadable. The man just stood there, sizing Luke up.
"You made it," the man said, his voice low. "Come in." Luke held out the phone, "Here." The man did not take it. "Things have changed," the man replied. "I need you to come further inside." Luke's instincts screamed at him to turn and leave. The man stepped aside, gesturing deeper into the dark. "You're part of this now. Let's finish it."

There's leaves, a couple of old Coke cans, a used condom, and now the sour remains of my last meal. At least I made it away from the place we keep our gear. Our stuff is underneath the overhang of a graffitied upper floor and not too much open to the weather.
Gradually my stomach calms.
I walk shakily over to the gear and wrap myself up in the old doona. I found it two or three months back at a donation bin and, even though it was a bit grubby, it's not too bad. Callum got his doona in a store. He made me distract the sales lady with questions about pillows while he took his five finger discount. Don't know how she didn't see - doonas are big after all. I felt like a little kid again inside my special world with someone in the kitchen making us hot chocolates.
Nat's left now, probably walking across to the pub already. Callum comes closer and sits next to me, part-way under the doona. I know what he's going to do and sure enough he's fussing at something and soon throws off the doona. He's breathing faster and pacing round our space.
'Comin' down to the foreshore?' he throws at me suddenly. I feel like crap but I know Callum wants to go especially now it's getting dark. 'Maybe,' I say. 'Just need to get warm. Give me a bit.'
Callum kicks at a pile of garbage. He comes over and leans down to look straight into my face, twisting his head sideways and making his eyes narrow. This is the look I get sometimes. I twist away a little, shaking.
'What's friggin' wrong with you?' he spits.
********************
There's no escaping the early light shafting through the pane-less window, even though it's pretty early. Sunlight reflects off some old tiles. This must have been a kitchen once.
Callum is still out to it. He stumbled in late last night and crashed out so quick. I pretended I was asleep. I do it sometimes but it doesn't always work.
My hip is burning 'cos I've been lying on it too long. A few layers of cardboard and my spare jeans spread out between don't make up for the concrete floor underneath us.
I sit up slowly, stretching my back and feeling pretty sick. I haven't eaten in a while and that probably doesn't help. I could go down to the IGA for a bread roll.
My small purse - the one I keep in my rucksack's concealed pocket - is empty but for some coins. There was a ten and twenty in there yesterday and it will be three days before my next payment. I look at Callum. I wish I could call him out on it. I move to the corner again and retch, quiet as I can.
********************
Two minute noodles soaked in cold water are not good, but I scrape out the mug anyway. Should have left them longer. I find my comb and pull it through my knotty hair, then sling on the stripy scarf, the one some lady left at a bus stop. Maybe I don't look so bad. I slip out of the building, being careful not to be seen. I walk the six blocks to the library. The route takes me past the IGA and the crisis centre. A middle aged woman wearing a blue fleece watches me pass. At the library I can use the toilet, get a proper drink, and sit in a comfortable chair. When I arrive and go out the back to our space I see that Nat is here again. Callum's still lying back in the doona, his hair all messy. I'm safe for a few minutes but I know Callum gets even worse after he's been talking to Nat.
********************

We'd scraped together enough coins to buy a large fries between us and they're good. A man with two dogs strides past, the breeze blowing through his jacket and ruffling the dogs' fur.
