The Threshold
By Janice Shaw
He inhabits a quiet, twilight world now.
Even the familiar sound of a beloved voice gently encouraging him to walk only elicits a couple of tail thumps and no more, despite the plea, "Come on Laddie, you can do it. Just a few steps, and we'll go into the garden to see the birds. You love that."
Despairing, the old man adjusts the crocheted wool blanket that cocoons the little body in grey softness and drops heavily into a nearby armchair. He reaches for the phone, steeling himself for the call, "It's Bonnie Ladd. ... Yes, soon as you can. ... After surgery it is. See you then."
When the eldest son arrives, he finds his father searching through a box of old photographs. "Remember this? It's our lad, reaching the finish line with nothing but sky underneath him."
He turns to the dog, illogically hoping a shared memory will change everything, "You were only a pup then. Young, full of life," and then he adds softly, almost to himself, "We all were."
The son enquires, "How is he? Any better?" But he can see for himself that the change is for the worse. He moves over to pat the immobile figure, stroking his ears in the way he knows the dachshund loves.
"I've called the vet." They sit, sharing the silence with the laboured breathing from under the rug. Finally, the man folds it back slightly in case the little animal is overheated, musing, "Your mother finished this only a couple of nights before the accident. I recall saying, 'What's the use, he's a puppy - he'll only chew it to pieces.' He never did, though. He cherished it from the first."
"I remember Mum crocheting every night in front of the television. She didn't even need to look because she knew the pattern so well. It's one of the few clear memories ...," his son replies.
"Didn't want a dog, you know. Worried about gnawed chair legs, the piano stool, shoes and slippers. Funny, the things you think are important. But your mum insisted and brought him home only a month before ... and he saved us all, after ...."
"I was being bullied, at primary school. Mum had gone and these boys were .... Anyway, when we saw how Laddie would shoot around the park, nothing would do us but to enter him into a race. I was supposed to be training him, although that was just struggling him into a harness, pointing him in the right direction and letting him go when the woman said, 'Release'.
"And didn't he run! I don't know if you understood how much the training and the excitement meant to me, at the time."
"Oh, I knew. You two boys were lost, and I was no better. I didn't know where to turn, and then you came up with this silly idea of a competition for the pup that turned out not to be so daft at all. It was the first time I saw you smile for so long that I thought you'd forgotten how. And your brother, who was starting to suck the corner of a blanket again and retreat into his own world after he came out of the hospital, he came back to us." The door opened with an, "Is he better?"
Neither spoke, until the man gestured toward the figure, "The vet will be here soon."
"The vet! No! You can't give up on him. He's a fighter!"
The man tried to explain the inexplicable, "It's not a question of courage. He's had enough. Laddie trusts me to do what's best. I'm not putting him through any more."
"You can't - there must be a treatment. Some medication, surgery, something!"
"Why must there be? He's old and frail. 'Here's our old soldier back again,' the vet would say when she saw him, surprised every year that he was still with us. Now it's time to let him go," the man naturally fell into the role of making hard decisions, despite his son being an adult many years.
"This isn't right!"
"Perhaps. But a pyrrhic victory is not right, either. We must accept that we have many years and he so few." The younger son turned to his brother, "You don't agree with this, do you? Can't we do something? Pay for the vet to take him to hospital?"
The other spoke gently, "Have money fix it? Do you remember when we wouldn't go to school or even get out of bed after Mum died, and Dad said that if Laddie could run a race with those little legs of his, trying even though he had no hope of winning, then we could do no less? That if he could keep going, so could we? Well, this is a finish line Laddie needs to cross without us."
"But he's been a part of my life for as long as I remember. He's all we have left of Mum."
Just then, a tentative tap on the door announced the intrusion into their grief.
He made one last appeal, "Dad, please don't do this. Tell her to come back tomorrow or send him to the clinic for treatment."
"No, son. You know I can't."
The man, as one does with one's children no matter their age, directed his sons to do what they knew they must, "Now give our Bonnie Ladd a last goodbye."
The elder brother held out the photograph, "Look at how happy he made us seeing him finish this race. He's flying! He may not touch this earth again now, but we'll have him with us always." And they patted the little dog snuggled down into the mist-coloured crocheted rug, while the man opened the door and ushered across the threshold the woman who would allow their loved one to fly once more.
The Machinist
By Julie Robinson
Now that she was here she was so pleased she came. The ocean stretched before her like a length of peacock taffeta under a clear cornflower-blue sky. The only sounds were the hollow thunk of gentle waves smacking the rock shelf and the breeze-muffled mews of circling seabirds.
The July sun was unseasonably bright, its buttery warmth melting down over her head, shoulders and arms. The air was thick and sticky with salt, she could smell it and taste it on her lips. She shivered suddenly, reached for the railing and gripped it tightly.
There was another side to the ocean, one that dragged you in and sucked you under like a huge washing machine with an agitator that didn't turn off with the flick of a switch. That belonged somewhere in the past with the gaudy beach umbrella that flew halfway up the beach and the almost-finished princess castle near a red bucket of pretty stones and shells.
They had all dropped on the sand like strands of limp seaweed after pulling her out, but she couldn't be consoled. At bedtime, Eileen had sat at her side stroking her hair till she finally broke free from the ocean's grasp. She woke again suddenly to George's bully-boy voice, reminding Eileen again that she was spoiling the child.
There was something white bobbing about out there, maybe a bird. Thankfully, there was no one close by save a man with binoculars. She was glad, she liked her own company and pleasing herself now that she could. It was some years since Eileen and George had passed, first one, then the other, with heart and cancer. She still felt their ghosts through the house: Eileen sipping black coffee and browsing the weekly catalogue specials; George flopped in an easy chair hogging the TV; Eileen in her quilted dressing gown and fluffy slippers playing solitaire; George tucking into three lamb chops at the tea table to their one.
What she would have done for an extra chop back then. She had got away from them for a time. That was in her working girl days when Eileen packed her a lunch of cheese sandwiches and an orange or apple.
Sometimes after an occasional Sunday roast she had cold meat scraps but mainly it was cheese. Slinging her work bag over her shoulder and still half asleep, she caught the early bus for a 7am start. She had her own machine like Bev, Pat, Sheila, Rosa and the others. One did sleeves, another buttons, one the two fronts and back. She was the collar and cuff girl. Life then was all about pins and cotton and bobbins and scissors, and the whir of Singers. Quotas had to be met or else, and supervisors watched you like a hawk. They loved their pound of flesh, that factory, and if you got caught nattering you were bawled out by the boss with words that tore you up, spat you out and sent you back to your machine in tears.
If it wasn't for the girls, the pay packet and the board money that was relied on, she'd be up and gone. Where she would go and what she would do, she had no idea. She kicked off her heels under the lunchroom table, they all did. Then over a cuppa forgot about needles and thread, and gossiped away time.
"Come on Joy," they teased, "tell us about that boy Bev saw you with at the pictures the other night."
"Must have been someone else," she grinned, "haven't seen a film in a while."
"That's what you tell us," ribbed Sheila.
"We want all the juicy bits," added Pat, "tell us everything, absolutely everything."
"Oh, you girls," she giggled, "all you think about is boys and more boys."
"Did you let him taste your new peppermint pink lipstick?"
A head poking in at the door and a "back to work, girls" growl was enough to shush them and save her the embarrassment of the truth. They were happy enough days but things took a turn when Sheila got the sack. She had gone to her gran's funeral and took two more days because of her monthlies. She had crept back to her bench as white as a sheet, tears streaming. They didn't have to be told. And there was George now, blowing his stack at breakfast. A headline in the newspaper, a photograph and his face screwed with rage. "What's this then Joy girl, and you'd better have a good answer?" he bellowed, thumping the table. He stormed to the sink and shoved the paper in her face.
"Is this you, or is it not you?" She stared at a picture of the meeting in town with the new union president. She was there all right, plain as day in the crowd. George had ranted on and on about the perils of Communism and how next she'd be on a plane to Moscow to celebrate May Day. Too right they were there and it was for Sheila and the others.
Things were never right at home after that. Da got angrier and Ma cried too much. Da got chest pains and Ma got thin. Skin and bone thin. Fear gripped her and her knuckles turned white. The ocean was drawing her, pulling her in and pushing her down into its murky depths. She struggled to breathe. Da was nowhere but Ma was calling with outstretched arms. She couldn't clasp Ma's hand. She tried and tried.
A nearby voice spoke softly, "Can you see them out there? Not as far out as the ship. Someone is swimming near dolphins."
Then, "Sorry, are you okay?"
She jumped at the stranger's voice. He passed Joy his binoculars. She caught a dolphin breaching and it was amazing.
The summer we turned thirteen
By Stephanie Ayres
It was the last week of the school year, and forecast for 35 degrees, so Josh and I had decided to cut school for the beach. It's not like we'd be learning anything, they'd probably be showing movies all day, and there's only so many times you can watch Avatar.
We'd packed our towels, boogie boards and a change of clothes; and made sure we had enough money to stuff ourselves stupid at the kiosk. I felt a bit sorry for the others sitting through lessons, but not too sorry. As we ran on the bus, the driver gave us a knowing look. It was going to be a scorcher, and the beach was the place to be. Sun, surf, sand, and freedom from Mr Simpson's pathetic lectures about "behaviour befitting the school". The more observant among us knew he and Miss Knight disappeared to the stationary cupboard during sports afternoons. How hypocritical can you be?
"Hey Josh," I asked, "What shade of lipstick do you reckon Homer will be wearing today?"
Josh roared with laughter. "I don't know, but it'll be the same shade as Knight in Shining Revlon."
We cackled so loud that some old Karen at the front gave us dirty looks. I gave her the bird and laughed some more. Josh had a healthy distrust of authority. He hid a bug in the staffroom when we were in primary school, and we heard first-hand how adults in power say stuff in private that they'd never say in public. Until then, it had never occurred to me. But then I'm not smart like Josh. A lot of people don't realise just how smart he is - maybe because he never makes a big deal out of it; never raises his hand in class, half the time doesn't even look like he's paying attention. Maybe it's because he hangs around with me. They called us dumb and dumber for a while, then they realised it was only half true. The waves were pumping as we made our way down the sand. There were guys on boards bobbing out the back and someone was erecting a volleyball net further down the beach.
"My mum reckons she was here the day that big ship washed ashore," I said.
"Grandma reckons there's wrecks all down Stockton breakwall."
We spent the whole day riding the waves, lying on the sand and stuffing ourselves with hot chips. As the morning stretched into afternoon, the wind started to pick up, and grey clouds built up on the horizon. As the sun dipped behind them, we walked up to the ocean baths and ran along the perimeter.
"Do you reckon it could turn into another Pasha storm?"
"That was in June. We might get hail though," he said.
Of course it was. Mum had told me that. I felt a bit stupid then. Josh went quiet then and looked out to the horizon. He looked like he was watching the storm clouds but there were other storm clouds moving in behind his eyes. I knew he spent the second half of the holidays at his dad's. He hated his dad - he was a nasty piece of work. I once asked him why he didn't just bug his dad's house like he bugged the staffroom, but Josh feared what his dad would do because he'd know it was him.
It was then I remembered the surprise in my bag. That would cheer him up.
"Hey, look at this!" Josh would think it was clever. He'd see that I noticed things too. I pulled out a phone from my bag. It was pink and covered in butterflies.
"What the hell is that?" He asked.
"It's Miss Knight's phone. I pinched it off her desk yesterday when she wasn't looking. I bet I can crack her passcode."
"Oh bullshit. If you could crack it, you would have done it by now."
He had a point, but I hadn't tried until now. I thought I would let Josh share in the thrill. I tried a few combinations, trying to mimic the movement of her finger on the screen. Teachers really shouldn't use their phones in class. After a few goes it unlocked.
"What the hell, man? You did it!"
I tried to get into her Facebook, but she'd logged out. I tried YouTube and a video of dashcam clips came up.
"Hey look, this just uploaded."
The first clip was a granny who mistook the accelerator for the brake, but the second showed a guy full on road raging: yelling, screaming and attacking another car with a baseball bat. The licence plate was not visible, but there was no mistaking the face.
"Josh, is that your..." Josh nodded dumbfounded. It was then that I truly understood.
I told him he should tell the police, but he was adamant his father would know. I knew then what I would have to do. I made a screenshot and logged onto a few websites, attaching the photo, or linking the video, and adding details about what the vision showed; and what it didn't. When it was done, I removed the evidence.
"Don't worry. I'll fix it. He'll never know. This is going to be a great Christmas." But Josh was scared. He didn't trust authority.
********************
Josh didn't have to go to his dad's those holidays, or any other holidays. They never did find out who dobbed him into the cops, because I'd logged in anonymously and removed the evidence. I wiped all my prints off Miss Knight's phone and slid it under the door of the stationary cupboard on Thursday morning. I'd tucked a stick of Estee Lauder under the clasp, to say thank you, and so she'd know she could do better.
Home-less
By Linda Mueller
Your home is brimming with love. Curtains flutter in and out; children's laughter escapes through the windows; the mum and dad sit on the verandah toasting the ocean view. Except it's not your home anymore, not since you shut the front door for the final time. The new owners know nothing of your pain, your desperate attempts to feed the mortgage beast, your pleading with the bank for one more month's reprieve.
It doesn't matter that you painted every intricate cornice, that you graced each wall with a memory, that you breathed love into every surface. It doesn't matter that it's there where you endured his bile and his blows, that man who shared your bed until he slid into someone else's. It doesn't matter that sometimes his blows punctured the walls or that you patched them up. It doesn't matter that repairs to your body and mind were never as easy. You stop stalking your old home and search for a new one but replacement homes are hard to come by. The lines are long at rental properties, filled with competition - 18-year-old uni students desperate to find the perfect share house, blokes in their 30s finally cast out of the family home, divorced women starting fresh - all with proof that they are the perfect tenant. You are overwhelmed with their steely commitment, their preparation, their "you must pick me and only me" stance.
You do not expect the Hunger Games. It frightens you so you back away, clutching your handbag, dragging your suitcase which contains all that you have left - some clothing, a few photos, a lonely can of deodorant and your favourite lipstick. You won't have a home but at least you'll smell sweet and you can give everyone a bright pink smile, if anyone bothers to look. Did you really think you could compete? Someone is sure to find out that you've got little chance of paying the rent beyond a couple of weeks, that you're waiting for Centrelink to find some compassion and a few more dollars in their vault for you, that you're still hoping to find that non-existent job that exists only for you.
You open your purse and count the dollars and cents of your last pay. You and your boss "agreed" it was best you move on, that you need time to "sort yourself out", that you will be "welcome back when the time is right". There's not enough energy in you to fight the words that spill from her mouth, let alone the unspoken words or the unknown quantity of time. You skulk back to your car, a battered bomb that barely makes it to 60, and throw your suitcase back into the boot. There's only so many spare beds at those women's shelters. So the bomb has become your home and you've learnt that sleeping in the foetal position on the back seat is almost comforting. If you park at the beach, it's a room with a view. Such versatility. You laugh at your attempt at a positive spin.
Your problem is you don't know how long it will be before you get told to move on. Already there's been suspicious looks from surfies and swimmers who arrive at dawn to tackle the waves. Not to mention the cars that arrive at night with occupants who move to the back seat before the engine cools. They look over at you before they duck their heads down. You find it hard to believe they would choose to fool around in a car when surely there's a choice of a bed somewhere, with clean sheets and soft pillows.
How long will it be before it becomes unsafe to sleep in your car? Before someone realises all you own is in this car. Locks and windows won't keep someone out if they really want to get in. You know you need to find somewhere less visible but obscure locations also mean danger. You could be attacked, robbed, left in a dark spot until daylight reveals your broken body. Bleak but realistic. Where's that positive spin now?
What you need is fresh air and a different view, to stretch your legs, to pretend you're just like any other walker at the beach, minus the designer joggers. Golden sand and the blue horizon invite you closer. Instead, you head up the hill, skirting the cliff, steering away from people.
It's easy to forget there's always another view if you look hard enough. Down the other side, there's a building, forlorn and neglected. Its cement structure is still intact but you notice that the windows are just openings. No fancy curtains, no glass. By Derek Fisher
I've been here before. This gutted hollow's walls were more chiaroscuro-charcoal back then, less comic-cartoon colours. The smell of decay and destitution still remains. Five years ago, I was 17, loving life as a hand-cam for hire, making music videos for urban-rap artists. Having trespassed many places so perfect for our purposes, we'd exhausted possibilities then heard a fire had recently ravaged Queens Wharf West. Incinerated quickly meant abandoned.
This time, I'm following Naomi. She makes social-realist documentaries, providing a mouthpiece for marginalised voices. We're here to see who's sheltering in the charred and blackened 'broken' at our feet. We find Ro.
"You'd never have found me if the bladder wasn't chirping up. Gotta go but. Gotta go."
And he does. Right there in the corner.
Naomi explains. "We're making a documentary about Newcastle's homeless to get their perspectives. Can I ask your name?"
"Ro will do."
"No worries, Ro. How would you feel about talking to us on camera?"
No reply, just a posture, a sculpture of recoil, a visceral reticence.
"We could record you off-camera? Use your voice-over to comment on the vision we shoot."
"Yeah." A slight nod. "Okay."
I set up fast, working invisibly to keep it natural and let the subject speak.
"This place has been ruined for years - "
"Five, actually," I unhelpfully interrupt.
"Since the fire," says Ro. "I read about it. I used to walk past with my partner on the way to get fish and chips. That was before."
Naomi says nothing. I try not to breathe too loudly.
"Yeah, that was before. We all have different versions of before but our afters are much the same. My 'before' was gambling, the pokies. I've spoken to others. Their 'before' might be domestic violence, unemployment, might be all-sorts."
Ro casts an arm around the room. "The 'after' is always a little bit a lot like this."
"I've met some characters doing the rounds - some help, some hurt. Gloria was luckily the first I knew. She taught me street-ways, homeless-hacks, transient-tricks. Golden rule: get shifty. Shift where you stay, then circle back through your cycle of options. Shift when you sleep, shift who you hang with. See life as a sequence of shifts, each with one goal - survival."
This time it's Naomi's breathing I hear then she says, "Can we get you in touch with any services? Get you checked out by a doc?"
"Thanks, I'm good. I know where to go when needed. The body takes a beating but, this life, it's hard on the mind, hard on the soul."
He coughs and, for some reason, so do we.
"Some of us thought we were going to die last year, asphyxiation by gas! Someone got under the building by water, drilled straight into gas-lines, trying to find copper they could nick and sell-on." He starts to nod like a metronome, like a stuck-needle, like a pigeon taking stock.
I'm antsy, uncomfortable, feeling my awkwardness of five years ago. Our rap-video was interrupted by a homeless man who growled until we bolted. We'd laughed, but heading home I clocked how much we middle-class pretenders were, well, pretending. We had bad-ass lyrics about hard-done lives bouncing off deep-bass beats. We had quick-cut edits and close-up sneers, fired-up fists of fury. We had no idea at all. Five years on, I've not much more to show.
"Have you spoken to others?" asks Ro, looking towards the harbour where the ferry chugs the churn.
"We just started," says Naomi. "You're the first homeless voice we've met. We began by filming council on their latest site-tour after the recent site-investigation." She turns. "Show Ro the clip!"
I can see, through jagged-edged apertures, down to where we filmed this footage, before being stopped from going further on the 'tour' being undertaken. Present were a councillor and building inspector in respective 'sort-of' uniforms plus a developer, very expensively suited.
I gesture Ro to check the screen. The three stand in a triangle, each like a trophy, feet planted firm and hands-on-hips.
The building inspector says the site's unusable, not fit for purpose. The councillor responds that the mission is to revitalise, re-energise.
The developer asks about consultation and other processes. The developer smiles. "So, we demolish early 2026?"
We look to Ro for a response. "Demolish?"
I re-jig the equipment for recording, take a panning shot, track through the glassless aperture, pulling out to high-angle tilt-down on the harbour's glistening water-views.
"You'll need to move on," says Naomi, "but they've taken so long, it may never actually happen."
"Anyway," I offer, "governments might start providing better places to lay your head?"
Ro looks out towards water-views beckoning him like a tide. We see the ferry, hear the cockroaches rustle. We hear the 'broken' in the refuse at our feet.
We hear Ro, gutted, hollow: "I've been here before."
Headspace
By Peter Rodgers
I went there yesterday, to mark your birthday. I lit a candle and drank a half-bottle of Prosecco. The place is as scruffy as ever, vivid with memory.
How I miss you there, how I miss us there. It's three years since I stumbled into that fractured room. Which one of us was most startled we'll never know.
"Sorry," I mumbled awkwardly as you rose from that ancient, threadbare lounge. "I didn't realise..."
"What do you want?" you demanded.
"I've often driven past this place and wondered."
"Wondered what?"
"What it was like inside. Who might have lived here, what happened to them? What they felt when they saw that?"
You followed my gaze to the lemony sky outside, the multi-tinted water, the infinite air. Your voice softened as you asked what I felt there. "Wonder," I breathed, "just wonder."
Silence, before I asked why you were there. You considered.
"I've had a diagnosis. Here there are no expectations, no demands on me. I can just be. I'll keep coming as long as I can."
"What about your family?" I asked. "They'll cope."
I thought that brusque, but when I met them I saw your confidence was well placed.
One day I pointed at the bright, anarchic colours daubed on the walls and asked, "What's the message there?"
"Who knows?" you said. "Protest, anger, disappointment about the world, maybe nothing at all. If you demand a message all the time, you ruin imagination. Wasn't the world more intriguing when the moon was made of cheese?"
You urged me to add to the art. I bought a green paint canister. It sat untouched for several months before an unknown visitor rewarded us with stylish four-leaf clovers. Lying on that cloverleaf in sleeping bags one night, you said you had news.
"You've seen the doctor again?" I asked, anxious. "No. The news is I've decided not to take you as a lover."
It took me a while to muster a response. "I didn't know I was an applicant."
"Come on, Jeremy," you replied, close to cross. "That possibility must have crossed your mind. I know I'm older, quite a bit actually, not at my best anymore. Still. Maybe I'm the one who should feel offended?"
"I thought briefly about one last fling, and you're an appealing candidate. But I couldn't manage it."
"Are you that ill?" I asked. "Not that. When friends become lovers, they must rebalance. That takes time, which we don't have. Okay?"
"Okay," I said, thankful the dark had masked my flushed, uncertain face.
I brought a picnic basket next time. As we ate, you said you'd been reading about the Queen. "After what you've said about her and all the royals?," I chided.
"Alright, alright! But she once described Balmoral Castle as her special place, her happy place. It has 167 rooms, 52 of which are bedrooms, so that just doesn't make sense."
"What do you mean?" I asked.
"Let's say one lived there full-time, spending a week in each bedroom. It'd take a whole year to do the circuit."
"One's point being?" I teased.
"That's just an extravagance, an indulgence, not a special place in the heart. Not like this," you added softly.
Next time we met, I asked what you thought left this place abandoned.
"A family got too large, too small, too greedy, too indifferent," you replied.
A small ferry, perfectly framed by the window mouth, glided across the water beyond. I pointed and said, "How could anyone become indifferent to a scene like that?"
"Maybe a dream went badly wrong," you ventured. "Dreams are prone to that. A catastrophe perhaps?"
"Such as?"
"A business partner cleaned out the vault and disappeared, a family member was killed?"
"Should I try to find out?" I asked.
"No, please don't." you sounded quite alarmed. "That might change everything for us. Remember what I said about the moon and cheese?"
We sat quietly. "You're so comfortable with silence. It intrigues me. Others are usually anxious to plug the gap."
"I'm only silent on the outside," you smiled. "On the inside it's often like a madhouse. I like our silences, though. I know there'll always be more good words when we need them."
"I'll miss you," I said.
"I'll miss you missing me," you laughed. "Please come to my funeral. But promise to stay away at the end. You should see me only here." I agreed.
"You sound disappointed."
"I'm sad," I said.
"One thing. Please collect some paint flakes from that crazy wall and sprinkle them over my grave."
"Wait till I'm in there, please," you laughed, wiping your eyes.
My days are busy. My job's unexciting but it pays the mortgage. When my two boys are older, I will take them to our place and tell them all about you. The ferries will intrigue them. I will hide my sorrow.
